00041 /// @file   util/FsPath.h
00042 /// @brief  A class for working with richer filepaths than just a string.
00043 
00044 
00045 // We are going to use unix conventions in the internal format
00046 // and translate them to the os requirements only as needed.
00047 // so we define these here.
00048 // They are not contitional on the platform. (unix & win32)
00049 #define FSPATH_PATHSEP "/"
00050 #define FSPATH_INTERNAL_PATHSEP ":"
00051 #define FSPATH_EXTSEP "."
00052 
00053 /**
00054  * @class FsPath
00055  * @brief  A class for working with richer filepaths than just a string.
00056  * APT would like to be able to name where to read and write data.
00057  * when there was just one dataset per file the filename was sufficient to
00058  * to do this.  The dataset name was simply mapped into the
00059  * file system. Now things are more complicated.  A file
00060  * can contain several datasets.
00061  *
00062  * Currently this is handled by also passing in more options
00063  * to name the group and table.  However this is done
00064  * different ways in APT.  The goal of FsPath is to be
00065  * able to name these datasets and provide a convenient set of
00066  * methods to work with the names.
00067  *
00068  * FsPath keeps its names in seperate pieces so the can be
00069  * worked on and recombined without parsing a string in the
00070  * code.  The directory name, file name, internal group name
00071  * and tablename (dataset) are all kept in the one object.
00072  * This FsPath can be passed to the File libraries who can
00073  * extract what they need.
00074  *
00075  * The format of the FsPath is:
00076  *     /os/path/name/filename.EXT:group/names/tablename
00077  *
00078  * (A) The path in the os. ("/os/path/name")
00079  * (B) The filename and extension. ("filename.EXT")
00080  * (C) The external/internal separator (":")
00081  * (D) The internal path. ("group/names")
00082  *     file5 could have several parts.
00083  *     calvin must have one and only one level of group names.
00084  *     TsvFile can be extended to use the filesystem to have groups.
00085  * (E) The tablename/dataset name ("tablename")
00086  *
00087  * With all this we could then write:
00088  *
00089  * FsPath path("path/to/file.EXT:/group/table")
00090  * DaoDataSet dataset;
00091  *
00092  * dataset->open(path);
00093  *
00094  * and the EXT would do the magic for Calvin, File5 or TsvFile.
00095  *
00096  * Thinking about this some more, it might be best to break out
00097  * the operating system calls into a seperate module which takes a string
00098  * or a FsPath object to do things with.
00099  *
00100  *  Note: according to APT-380, "Desktop" and other special windows dirs
00101  *  might be flagged as write-only, but actually be writeable.
00102  *  If this is really the case then "isWriteable" should be a two step process:
00103  *    if (s_writeable()) { return true; }
00104  *    if (is_windows()) { if (try_and_make_a_dir_works()) { return true; } }
00105  *    return false.
00106  *
00107  * Ideas:
00108  * * Add "void*" to the actual file being opened for reference.
00109  *   and marker for what type is being held.
00110  *
00111  *
00112  * To migrate current functionality:
00113  * - UncPath() here
00114  * - BaseName()
00115  * - FileRoot()
00116  * - Openers for raw streams.
00117  * - IsWritable() or equivalent
00118  */
00119 class FsPath {
00120   public:

00122   /// Codes for the different formats APT might expect files to be in.
00123   enum FileFmt_t {
00124     FILEFMT_NONE = 0,
00125     FILEFMT_ANY,
00126     FILEFMT_AUTO,
00127     //
00128     FILEFMT_CALVIN,
00129     FILEFMT_FILE5,
00130     // we dont read straight text, but APT might know it is a text file
00131     FILEFMT_TEXT,
00132     FILEFMT_TSVFILE,
00133   };
